course.post_excerpt:
Drag, scale, position, customize and see every edit you make to your WordPress website on the front-end – in real-time – with Upfront.

In this five-part course, learn how to use the Upfront theme framework with fun lessons and practical examples you can try out on our demo website. By the end of the course, you’ll have solid experience in editing themes and will have your own stunning Upfront website.

course_settings.course_subtitle: Learn how to create beautiful websites with WPMU DEV’s powerful theme framework.

1133978.comment_content:
Hey, Mike.

Open Upfront builder.  Here are the steps you need to follow to add the pages.

1. Drag and drop menu element in place.
2. Click on the menu element on your page.
3. Create a new menu if you have not created on.  Then save.
4.  Click on the gear icon in the menu element on your page.
5. On you left you will see Setting.  
6. Find General Settings. Select menu.
7.  Next to menu structure click the add new button to add new item (x3).
8.  Open the new item. Rename the label to (eg blog).  Open the link and find the page or post menu item in the drop down box.  Click it.
9.  A box to your right will open.  Select the page you want to link to your menu item. Click OK.
10. When done.  Go back to your left. Click the OK button at the bottom of your Settings tab.

If you are still struggling to add menu items, please pop into live chat so our tech team can take a look.  Please let me know if this worked for you.
1133978.comment_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/59.0.3071.115 Safari/537.36

1133978.comment_content:
Hey, Marketingdoc.

To add the menu items to your menu here is what you need to do.

1.  Click anywhere on the menu.
2.  Click on the gear icon in the top left of the menu box.
3.  To the left, the edit screen will appear.  Then click on the - Add Menu button.
4.  Then click on the - New Item.
5.  Click on the - Link To.
6.  Go down the drop down menu.  Find Post and Pages.  Click on it.  A box will appear to your right.  Find the page you want to add.  Click on it and then click OK.
7.  Go back to the edit menu screen.  Give your Menu a New Name.  This will appear in the Menu.
8.  Repeat for the second Page you want to add to your menu.
9.  When done.  Click the OK button.

Your pages will now show in your menu.

Contact form

Our contact form is really basic.  For what you want to do,  I would suggest going with a plugin like ContactFrom7.  You can create different contact forms and then just add them to the page or section with the shortcode.

Please let me know if you come right.

Here's my biggest fear at this point. The client is not in a glamorus industry: direct mail. I want to build a landing page to give the visitor in seconds that there is not only direct mail. The header of the page will shout out something like  "PIEDMONT DIRECT… Enabling Your Company To Achieve A Better Advertising Response Using DIRECT MARKETING and MAIL for Each Advertising Campaign. The final text box, Who is Piedmont? 25 Plus Years of Direct Marketing Mail in North Carolina and the United States. We have Invested in Technology and Skilled People to Take Your Marketing and Mail Projects from Concept to 
Reality.

At this point, a website visitor has a good idea, that the provider is using direct marketing and mail, for small business marketing. 1133978.comment_content:
I have been chiseling Wordpress setup the "WPMU-way" so far. Then today I have started learning Upfront by taking this course and I had to immediately try out the support: Upfront editor did not open and the starter theme (Spirit) was just a blank white page in Chrome while it was about ok in IE11. Luis has quickly and professionally resolved the case by suggesting to turn off Rocket Loader in CloudFlare service (which is a javascript optimizer service in beta state, anyway).
Well, I'm at this point now.

What am I planning to build with Upfront?
I have to (re)make a corporate website. The previous version was also made by myself back in 2004 with Swish (a kind of Flash editor). It became outdated enough and also, if there was a need for changing some info on the website, it took too much time.
I want the new website to be edited by "anyone" (yeah, it will be me, again) easily and fast, without pixel-positioning new text or recompiling .swf files for all the language versions of the site. Also, it would be good if the initial development were fast and easy, as well. (Yeah, unfortunately we cannot avoid image editing and effecting anyway.)

Did I make a good decision by choosing Wordpress + Upfront? ;)
We'll see. I did not tell the company about my decision yet. Hopefully they gonna like it and take over the monthly subscription... :P

Hi Jimmy,

I do understand your frustration as the design of the quizzes isn't ideal and we're working on making improvements, just have a backlog of other improvements our front-end team is working on across the WPMU DEV site at the moment so it may take a little while. 

I reviewed the video and I think you may have gotten Jenni's example a bit confused. There are two ways to download Upfront: a, with the Dashboard plugin, or b, the old-fashioned way by directly downloading an Upfront theme from our site and then uploading it *similar* to how you would install any other theme, like a WordPress.org for instance. As far as the quiz goes, I'm going to update all Upfront quizzes in a sec so you only need to get 80%. We've recently updated all other Academy course quizzes so you need 80%, this course is just the last to be updated.

I do hope you are enjoying the course and not getting too frustrated! If you run into any troubles in future, don't hesitate to comment in the discussions and ask for help or a clarification as we have facilitators on hand to help answer your questions.

Cheers, Rae (Academy Facilitator)

1133985.comment_content:
Hey, Tom.  Lets see if I can help you with this. By writing the steps.  But I think I will make a video for your guys as well, but that will only be sometime next week.
Download instantwp.
Click to install.
Click instantwp to open the file.
Click on the icon that looks like a man running.
Click on open Plugins Folder or Theme Folder.  
Copy and paste the downloaded folder (in this case it will be the wpmudev dashboard).
Extract the file.
Then delete the zip file and close the folder.
Then click on the WordPress Admin tab.  This will open the admin part of WP.  Activate your dashboard(wpmudev) and download you plugins and themes as normal.

Please let me know if you have come right.  Next week I will create a tutorial on instantwp for you.

1133992.comment_content:
Hey guys.

I have been reading your comments.  There seem to be confusions regarding the editing of the theme.  Remember that when you activate your chosen theme.  You must also activate the page templates provided by your theme for the pages you created.  
When you edit in Upfront you are editing the page template and not the actual page.  Page templates act like virtual pages.
There are two ways to edit a theme.  One is when you activate it.  The other one is when you use the builder straight.
Also remember that when you create a new page, Upfront saves it as a template.  That is if you are creating a new theme from scratch.

Hope this helps you to understand the editing prossess a little better.

Michelle

1133992.comment_content:
Hey Margie.

To make a region smaller.  Here is what you have to do:

1.  Let the mouse pointer go to the far right of the screen.  The region will make a little fold in the top corner.
2.  Click on the gear icon.
3.  The region will now have yellow plus signs and a yellow short, thick line at the bottom.
4.  Click and hold the line.
5.  Drag it upwards or downwards to increase or decrease the space.
6.  Save the region by clicking the light green button.

And that is it!  You have successfully edited your region spacing.

:-)  Michelle

1133998.comment_content:
A global region can be any region you want to display on each and every page of your site.  Remember that if you make a region global it will be the same on every page.  That is why I gave the header and footer as an example as this is going to appear on every page of your site.  Imagine if you had to put the header and the footer region on 500 pages individually.  You would feel overwhelmed.  Not to mention if you wanted to change something like the background.  You will have to do this 500 times.
You can make a newsletter subscription form that you place just above the footer area global.   With a global region, you just have to edit once to make the change appear on each and every page at once.

1133998.comment_content:
Hey, kk.

Upfront builder is what you are using to build/edit your website.  Regions are sections on a page that you divide your website with.  It will also help you re-use some sections on other pages because you won't have to redesign it again.
The elements are the building blocks of your site. 
Header region (global)
Content region (can be anything you want)
Footer region (global)
The best advice I can give you here is to install one of the child themes and then to see what kind of reasons there are on the pages.

1133998.comment_content:
Hey, kk.

When you make a region global it means that it will look the same on every page.  Global regions are best used in header and footer areas where you need everything to look the same.  When you have a global region it simply means that when you make a change it will take effect in that specific global regions.
Let's take the footer for example.

Say you want to change the background color.  You just have to do it once.  Whereas if you have a none global region.  You will have to make the change in each and every region separately.

1133998.comment_content:
Hey, guys.

Presets are a great way to re-use designs.  Say for instance you want a text block to have a red background with white text, but you don't want it for every text element.  Then create a preset for the element. Name it and save - red block with white text.  Then where ever you want to have it appear, just create the element and then change the default preset to the one you created.  This saves a lot of time.
1133998.comment_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/57.0.2987.133 Safari/537.36

1133998.comment_content:
Hey, kk.

When working with presets, here is what you need to do.
1. choose the element
2. Drag and drop where you want it.
3. Create a new preset and name it.
Now, whenever you want an element to look like the previous one.  All you need to do is apply the preset you created to it.

1134006.comment_content:
Hey, kk.

Technology is great, but can sometimes be very frustrating.  If you should upgrade your hardware at some time, please note that what you want is the Ram.  The more Ram you have, the more running power you add to your device.  Each program you run will use a certain amount of Ram(temporary memory). This includes things like your operating system and everything else it needs to run.  Of course, your CPU is important too.  But we are just talking here about being able to have things (more than 5 - 10 processes) run without you wanting to break the device out of frustration.  So next time you buy a new device (laptop, etc.)  you will know to look for no less that 4 - 8 GB of Ram in the device.  Mine has 4, but it is still not enough.  I need to upgrade to 16 as I need to have things run and open in the blink of an eye.
1134006.comment_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/58.0.3029.110 Safari/537.36

1.title: Course Introduction
1.description:
Upfront is a theme framework for WordPress that allows you to drag and drop, scale, position, customize and see every edit you make to your website as you make it in real-time.

But what does that mean exactly? I like how WebDesignerDepot’s review explains Upfront:

"Upfront is, technically a WordPress theme, in the same way that a T-Rex is technically a lizard. In reality, it’s a whole lot more than that: Upfront allows you to customize your site — not just the content, the design too — without ever logging into the WordPress dashboard.”

There are a lot of page builders for WordPress, like Headway, Pagelines, Divi and iThemes Builder. So how is Upfront any different?

Upfront makes customizing the design of your site so easy you’ll never need another WordPress theme.

In this five-part course, I’ll introduce you to Upfront, walk you through how to use it with some fun examples you can try out for yourself on our Upfront demo site and, hopefully, open your eyes to the infinite possibilities that come with building websites with Upfront.

"I find it difficult to believe there is a particular layout that can’t be created with Upfront.” Chris Lema, WordPress blogger

Let’s get started!

Note: Before you get started, keep in mind that if you run into problems with any of the steps below it's best to refer to our Upfront Docs for comprehensive instructions. This course is a getting started guide so we're introducing you to how the framework works so you can start editing your own websites right away.

2.title: Tasks
2.description:
In order to complete this unit, Getting Started, read through the tutorial, watch the video, do the homework, and then complete the multiple choice quiz.

If you have any questions or thoughts about the course material, feel free to chat with fellow students and course facilitators in the unit discussion.

Good luck!

1133975.post_content:
Downloading, Installing and Activating Upfront

You’ve got two options when it comes to setting up Upfront on your website:
  1. Download an Upfront starter theme and upload the ZIP file to your WordPress site
  2. Download the WPMU DEV Dashboard plugin and auto-install an Upfront starter theme from the backend of your website
Note: Upfront comes pre-packaged with every starter theme.

1. Direct Download

Check out our starter themes and choose one you would like to explore for this tutorial. [pic_full_screen ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1364"] Our stunning Upfront starter themes are ready out-of-the-box and are completely customizable.[/caption] [/pic_full_screen]

2. WPMU DEV Dashboard Plugin

  • Download the Dashboard plugin and install it as a plugin on your WordPress site
  • Click on WPMU DEV in the sidebar and log in to your account
  • Go to Themes, choose the Upfront starter theme you would like to explore as part of this tutorial, and click Install
  • Once installed, click Activate
Upfront is now installed!

Getting Started With the Upfront Editor

Now that you’re all set up with Upfront, let’s take a look around. There are three ways you can access the Upfront editor:
  1. From the WPMU DEV themes page where you just installed Upfront (if you used it via the Dashboard plugin) you can click Customize
  2. In the WordPress admin, go to Appearance > Customize
  3. Click Upfront in the admin toolbar at the top of the page to launch the visual editor.
[pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Click on the Upfront link in the tool bar to go to the Upfront editor.[/caption] [/pic_full] The editor is split into two main sections: the Upfront sidebar on the left and your chosen theme on the right. Quick note: Why have we used pixelated images in all our starter themes? Easy: due to copyright, but mostly to ensure file sizes are small and so the editor loads fast. Images generally tend to bulk out theme files and we want to get you started as quickly as possible. [pic_full_screen ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1364"] When you fire up the Upfront editor, the sidebar on the left will display tools for editing your site, and the space on the right will display the current page you're editing.[/caption] [/pic_full_screen]

Editing with Upfront

OK, let's actually edit something. For now, we'll start small. (We'll do a lot more editing in the next tutorial.)

Resizing, Moving, and Deleting

Let’s start with resizing an image. In the Upfront editor, hover over an image, click one of the white handles that appears on the left, right and bottom, and drag it to your desired size. Moving an element is even easier. If you want to move an element, such as text or an image, hover over it and click and hold to drag anywhere on the page. To delete an element, simply hover over the one you want to remove and click the red “x” that appears in the top-right.

Editing Text

Editing text in Upfront is simple. All you need to do is double-click on a text area, and if you double-click again to select a word (or triple-click to select a paragraph), the text editing toolbar will pop-up, giving you the following options:
  • Type Element - This includes H1, H2, H3, H4, H5, H6, P and code format
  • Bold - Make text bold
  • Italics - Italicize your text
  • Alignment - Left, center and right align or justify your text
  • List - Create a bulleted or numbered list
  • Blockquote - Create a blockquote
  • Link - Link text to a URL, post or page, anchor or a lightbox element
  • Inline Icons - Insert an icon
The text editing toolbar includes icons, which you can make as big or as small as you like, as well as adjust their vertical alignment. When you’re done using the toolbar, just click elsewhere on the page and the toolbar will disappear.

Using the Upfront Sidebar

Now that you've had a go at basic editing, let’s explore the sidebar. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Access pages, posts, media and your profile from the top of the sidebar.[/caption] [/pic_full]
  • Upfront logo - Click to return to your homepage from anywhere on your site
  • Exit logo (three dots) - Click to return to the WordPress admin
  • The name and role of the current user
  • Edit profile - Click to edit your profile in the WordPress admin
  • New Post - Create a new post within the editor
  • New Page - Create a new page within the editor
  • Post/Pages - View, edit or trash posts and/or pages
  • Media - View your media files
So that’s the top part of the sidebar explained. Let’s take a look at some more interesting stuff: draggable elements and theme settings.

Draggable Elements

From images and text to galleries, maps and buttons, Upfront allows you to drag and drop elements anywhere on your site. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Draggable elements let you add all the page parts you need for your theme.[/caption] [/pic_full] Upfront’s 16 elements provide the core functionality or your website. Let’s go over what they are briefly now since we’re going to check them out in more detail later on in this course.
  • Text - Create a new text area anywhere on your site. Once created, just double-click and enter your text.
  • Images - Add a new image to your site. Just drag-and-drop the element where you would like to display the image.
  • Gallery - The gallery elements allows you to display, well, a gallery! There are lots of options for styling, re-ordering, positioning, captions etc.
  • Slider - Create a slide, add images, text over images, auto-rotate (or not), select a transition, show or don’t show slider controls, and more.
  • Map - If you’ve ever spent ages setting up a map on your site, you’ll be blown away by how easy it is to do with Upfront.
  • Menu - Display your menus anywhere, just drag the element across and choose the menu you would like to display.
  • Widget - With Upfront, your whole site is widgetized, which means you can place widgets anywhere on your site. Pretty cool, huh? You can display any of the default WordPress widgets, such as pages, calendar, and archives, or choose any other widget created by your plugins.
  • YouTube - Create a new video, just enter a URL.
  • Like Box - Or should I say, Facebook Like Box. Enter the URL for your Facebook page and hit enter. The element will update to show all of your Facebook followers.
  • Contact - The contact element lets you display a simple form with name, email and message fields.
  • Code - The Code element allows you to embed or write custom code that will be executed when your theme is live, so it's handy for embedding third-party videos not supported by our YouTube element, or adding custom scripts to your page.
  • Tabs - If you want to display more content in less space, tabs provide a slick solution. The tabs element comes with basic styling inherited from your theme.
  • Accordion - Much like the Tabs element, the Accordion element is a great option if you want to display a lot of content in a small space.
  • Button - Whether you want to add a link to another page on your site or a link where users can download a product, the Button element lets you create and style a button to match your site.
  • Login - With the Login element, you can place a login form anywhere on your site.
  • Posts - Last, but not least, the Posts element lets you display a single post or a list of posts. You can also choose whether to display an excerpt or a full post.

Theme Settings

Upfront allows you to control all of your theme's typography and colors from one central location, saving you the hassle of changing the colors of individual elements every time you change your mind. This means you can control your fonts and colors – and maintain consistency across your site – for things like text, borders, backgrounds, colors… everything! It’s like a color palette for your site. Let's go through the settings. Typography Tab:
  • Theme Fonts Manager - See which fonts you have installed on your site and download new ones from Google Fonts.
  • Type Element - Here you can choose which type you would to edit, i.e. H1, H1, p, anchor links.
  • Typeface - Select a typeface for your chosen type element, including any Google Fonts you have installed.
  • Weight/Style - You can style your type here depending on which font you've chosen and the styles it offers.
  • Color - Pretty self-explanatory!
  • Size - This one's pretty obvious, too!
  • Line Height - Change up the space between your lines of text
Below these options you'll see there are further settings for Global Theme CSS, Global Theme Background, and Editing Global Regions. These are advanced options, which we'll explore in another tutorial. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Set the typography you want to use in the Theme Settings, ensuring your have a consistent look and feel across your entire site.[/caption] [/pic_full] Color Tab: The Color tab allows you to set a color palette for use across your site. This is actually one of my favorite little features in Upfront because it makes designing sites really easy. For example, if I want my paragraph text to be a dark grey, like #333, all I need to do is click on the first color setting, ufc0, enter the color and click Ok. Once set, this color will be accessible every time I access colors on my site. Another great feature of the color settings is that you can use theme colors in your CSS by using their variables as you could HEX values, e.g. color: #ufc1. How cool is that?! [pic_full ] [/pic_full]

Using a Starter Theme

We've designed and built a collection of Upfront starter themes to make it simple to jump right in and start designing. Each of our starter themes as been crafted by our in-house team of designers with real small businesses in mind, so you know that they include all the elements needed for real world businesses to get a website up and running really quickly. I should explain why we call them starter themes. Technically, Upfront themes are child themes – Upfront is a parent theme and the starter themes are child themes. You can check out the WordPress Codex for a more in-depth explanation of how child themes work. The great thing about our starter themes is that while they provide stunning designs up front (pun totally intended!), you can customize them any way you like, even strip them completely and start from scratch (though in that case, you might like to install our Upfront Builder, but we'll get to that later...). [pic_full_screen ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1364"] Our stunning Upfront starter themes are ready out-of-the-box and are completely customizable.[/caption] [/pic_full_screen]

Upfront Settings

When you install Upfront, a new menu item will appear in the WordPress admin bar. Let's take a brief look at the options provided.

General

Here, you can:
  • Check which versions of Upfront and your chosen theme you have installed,
  • Access Upfront tutorials,
  • Enter an API for Google Maps and the Map element,
  • Access debug options,
  • Reset your theme to its original design, and
  • See the Upfront changelog.
Quick note: It's worth pointing out that when you reset your theme, it will delete your entire theme and reinstall it, so don't click the big red button unless you're completely and 100% sure you don't need your existing site anymore. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] It's a good idea to backup your site before clicking the red button.[/caption] [/pic_full]

User Restrictions

Here you can control different actions that your users can perform on your site, making it even easier to hand over your Upfront site to a client or run it on your Multisite network. Control what the editor, author, contributor and subscriber user roles on your site are able to see and do with Upfront. Some members who manage Multisite networks asked us “How do we stop users from modifying stuff?” Now you can set access to 17 different types of functionality. Want to restrict subscribers from loading Upfront and changing your layout? Done. Or stop contributors from uploading photos of their cats. You can do that, too. You can even completely turn off access to Upfront for all users on your site except admins and super admins. Note: If you're new to Upfront, it's probably a good idea to leave these settings alone for now and come back to them later when you've developed your site and have a need for user restrictions.

Experimental

This screen provides advanced features designed for developers. Note: I wouldn't recommend touching this section if you're a new user.

We’re Just Getting Started...

We've only scratched the surface of what's possible with Upfront. There's so much more to learn and customize! In this tutorial you learned:
  • How to download, install and activate Upfront,
  • How to get started using the Upfront editor and make basic edits, including moving, resizing, and deleting elements, as well as styling text,
  • How to use the Upfront sidebar, and
  • Using starter theme, and
  • Accessing Upfront's settings.
I hope you've enjoyed this tutorial and it's opened your eyes to the possibilities of Upfront! In the next unit, we'll explore how to use regions and elements to create beautiful layouts for Upfront.

1133977.post_content:
You've read through the tutorial and now it's time to get practical. The best way to help cement new information you've learned is to put it to practice. So after each tutorial in this course, you'll get self-assessed homework so you can try out different features in Upfront. This lesson, your homework is to:
  1. Install and activate Upfront and the Fixer theme on a site you can safely play on while you take this course (I recommend setting up WordPress locally on your computer. Not sure what that means? Check out our article Top 8 Best Ways to Set Up a Testing Environment for WordPress.
  2. Open the Upfront editor. Replace the existing logo with your own.
  3. Resize the text "We Build and Fix" that displays over the slider so it appears as one line and change its color to black in the Theme Settings
  4. Delete the calls to action in the header.
  5. Save your theme.

1133978.post_content:
Welcome to the first discussion for Introduction to Upfront! In this first unit, you learned:
  • How to download, install and activate Upfront,
  • How to get started using the Upfront editor and make basic edits, including moving, resizing, and deleting elements, as well as styling text,
  • How to use the Upfront sidebar, and
  • Using starter themes, and
  • How to access Upfront’s settings.
What has been your experience been like so far using Upfront? What kind of website are you planning to build with Upfront? This discussion is your opportunity to ask any questions and chat with other students and course facilitators.

3.title: Assessment
3.description:
At the end of each unit, you are required to complete a multiple choice quiz based on the concepts you learned about in the tutorial and video. You need to achieve an 80% score in order to pass and move on to the next unit in the course.

If you find the quiz tough, it's because we've made it deliberately challenging – we want you to think about what you've learned (and really earn the certificate at the end of the course!). Each of the questions is based on what's been covered in the course material so if you've paid attention you should have no problems.

Good luck!

1133979.post_content:
Take your time, read through the questions and, if you need to, go back to the tutorial and video and review what you’ve learned before answering the quiz questions.

Good luck!

1133980.post_content:
Congratulations! You have successfully completed Getting Started!

Now that you’ve made a start learning how to use the Upfront interface, let’s take a look at how to use regions and elements.

You can now proceed to the next unit, Working with Regions and Elements.

page_description:
a:3:{s:6:"page_1";s:2399:"

Upfront is a theme framework for WordPress that allows you to drag and drop, scale, position, customize and see every edit you make to your website as you make it in real-time.

But what does that mean exactly? I like how WebDesignerDepot’s review explains Upfront:

"Upfront is, technically a WordPress theme, in the same way that a T-Rex is technically a lizard. In reality, it’s a whole lot more than that: Upfront allows you to customize your site — not just the content, the design too — without ever logging into the WordPress dashboard.”

There are a lot of page builders for WordPress, like Headway, Pagelines, Divi and iThemes Builder. So how is Upfront any different?

Upfront makes customizing the design of your site so easy you’ll never need another WordPress theme.

In this five-part course, I’ll introduce you to Upfront, walk you through how to use it with some fun examples you can try out for yourself on our Upfront demo site and, hopefully, open your eyes to the infinite possibilities that come with building websites with Upfront.

"I find it difficult to believe there is a particular layout that can’t be created with Upfront.” Chris Lema, WordPress blogger

Let’s get started!

Note: Before you get started, keep in mind that if you run into problems with any of the steps below it's best to refer to our Upfront Docs for comprehensive instructions. This course is a getting started guide so we're introducing you to how the framework works so you can start editing your own websites right away.

";s:6:"page_2";s:338:"

In order to complete this unit, Getting Started, read through the tutorial, watch the video, do the homework, and then complete the multiple choice quiz.

If you have any questions or thoughts about the course material, feel free to chat with fellow students and course facilitators in the unit discussion.

Good luck!

";s:6:"page_3";s:576:"At the end of each unit, you are required to complete a multiple choice quiz based on the concepts you learned about in the tutorial and video. You need to achieve an 80% score in order to pass and move on to the next unit in the course. If you find the quiz tough, it's because we've made it deliberately challenging – we want you to think about what you've learned (and really earn the certificate at the end of the course!). Each of the questions is based on what's been covered in the course material so if you've paid attention you should have no problems. Good luck!";}

1.title: Unit Introduction
1.description:
From full-page video backgrounds and sliders to galleries, buttons and widgets, Upfront does it all with regions and elements.

Regions are the backgrounds you can add to every page of your site to create headers, footers, and sections for your content.

Elements are blocks of text, images, buttons, menus, galleries, contact forms, maps, custom code and more, which you'll find out more about in-depth further into this tutorial.

In this tutorial, we'll explore what regions and elements are all about and how to use them in the Upfront editor.

Let's get started.

2.title: Tasks

1133982.post_content:
Adding, Deleting and Editing Regions

Let's kick off with regions. When it comes to laying out your website with Upfront, regions provide the building blocks you need to create everything from fullscreen and full width headers, to contained sections, sidebars, and footers. Think of regions as the background on top of which everything else – images and text, video and sliders – are placed upon. You can have as many regions as you want on a page, and build regions around one another to create visibly different sections of content on your site, including headers and footers. To add a new region, hover over the top-right of an existing region your site (assuming you are using a starter theme, such as Fixer) and click the edit icon that appears. Check out the example below: [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Clicking on the edit region button gives you access to many background settings.[/caption] [/pic_full] Click on one of the + buttons to the top, bottom, left or right to add a new region. Adding regions to the left or right creates sidebars. Once you have chosen a location for your new region, give it a name. The name you choose is for your eyes only as it won't be displayed to visitors. Region names allow you to keep track of your page content and select particular regions later should you want to create headers or footers. But we'll get to that later.
Once you've created your new region, you can start customizing and styling it right away. Click the green gear icon to see the options available:
  • You can edit the name of your region
  • Enable auto resizing if you select sizing in the options below
  • Choose from different width sizes for your region such as
    • Full screen — A setting for headers only that automatically stretches the region to the entire size of the browser window
    • 100% wide — Fill the entire width of the page
    • Contained — Content is restricted to a certain size that you can adjust under Theme Settings > Global Theme BG
  • Select a Background Type
    • Solid color
    • Image
    • Video
    • Image Slider
    • Map
  • Adjust the top and bottom padding
  • Add optional custom CSS
  • Sticky the region, which ensure the region is in view at all times as you scroll down the page
You can also adjust the size of the background manually by clicking and dragging the yellow resizing button at the bottom edge of the region. And if you want to delete the region, simply click the red X button in the top, right-hand corner. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] To resize a region, simply click and drag and yellow bars at the top and bottom of regions. These bars appear when you're in the editing mode for regions.[/caption] [/pic_full] When you're done and happy with your changes, click the green Finish editing background button. Don't forget to click Save in the Upfront sidebar to save your changes.

Working With Elements

Let's move on to elements. While regions provide the building blocks needed to structure your site, elements provide the core functionality. All up there are 16 available elements that allow you to create everything from basic text areas to gorgeous galleries, Google Maps, sliders, and even custom coded solutions. To add a new element to your web page, click and hold any element from the Upfront sidebar and drag it onto the page where you want it to appear.

Resizing Upfront Elements

You can resize an element in one click by hovering over the one you want to adjust and white bars on the edges will be revealed. Click and drag them around until you're happy with the element's size, then let go of your mouse click. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] When you click on any element, white bars for resizing will appear on all sides. Just click and drag.[/caption] [/pic_full] You can click to resize them again if you want, but otherwise, you're done.

Deleting Upfront Elements

If you want to delete an existing element, hover over it with your mouse and look for the X button in the top-right corner. Click on it and poof! The element is gone. Almost like magic. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="670"] Click the red x icon to delete an element.[/caption] [/pic_full]

Right-Click Options

When you click on an element, you will see a set of icons displayed at the top of the element, which offer further settings. You can also right-click on an element to see extra settings, including Save, Undo and Clone. The cloning option lets you make an exact copy of the element to use elsewhere on the page. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Right-clicking an element reveals further editing options.[/caption] [/pic_full]

Customizing Upfront Elements

By single or double-clicking on an element, you can find extra options for further customization. Some elements have settings exclusively displayed in the menu on the left and others also display buttons over the element, which you can click to reveal more options. Here are the elements you can add to your site and how you can customize them to your liking in a few clicks. I'll also touch upon some of the key settings. [pic_left ]
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="490"] When you double-click text, the Text element displays an editing toolbar.[/caption]

Text

Adding text elements to your site allows you to create paragraphs of text, headers, sub-headers, lists and other text formats. Double-click on a text element after you've dropped it on the page to replace and customize the default dummy text. You can also find styling and typography options in the Upfront sidebar.
[/pic_left] [pic_right ]

Image

Drag an image element across to your page to add single images to your site. Adding a new image will upload it to your media gallery. You can then adjust and crop your image as needed. Clicking once on the element will display three buttons for further options, as well as the gear icon for even more settings.
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="490"] When you click "Add Image," you can upload new images to you media gallery.[/caption]
[/pic_right] [pic_left ]
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="490"] When you create a new gallery, there are lots of options for styling and re-arranging the order of images.[/caption]

Gallery

After dropping this element onto your page, you'll be prompted to choose whether an image thumbnail should link to the larger image in a lightbox or if it should link to an external page. Then, you can add your images. Clicking on individual images will throw up further options for styling and rearranging how your pictures look and are positioned in your gallery.
[/pic_left] Hovering over a thumbnail reveals settings for that individual image and clicking on the element once reveals three buttons with other customization options for all images within your gallery element. The gear icon also includes additional settings that are displayed in the Upfront menu. [pic_right ]

Slider

If you prefer to feature multiple images by using a slider, you can use this element. Adding it to the page reveals options for how and if you want to display a text overlay, then you can upload or select an image already in your image gallery. Clicking on the slider element once it's on your page reveals buttons for additional options, some of which are displayed in the Upfront menu.
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="490"] Create sliders of all shapes and sizes and with different transitions with the Slider element.[/caption]
[/pic_right] [pic_left ]
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="490"] You'll soon discover adding Google Maps to your site is actually kinda fun![/caption]

Map

Adding a Google map of a location is super easy. After dragging it onto the page, you can enter the address you want to showcase and voilà! You're done. No messing around with code, just simple drag-and-drop. There are other settings for customizing how your map looks, and you can enter your Google map API key by leaving the Upfront editor and going to Upfront > General in your admin dashboard.
[/pic_left] When you've got the hang of using Upfront, you might want to check out Snazzy Maps, which allows you to style how your Google Maps look in Upfront. Simply go to the Snazzy Maps website, choose a map you like the look of, copy the accompanying JavaScript and paste it into the Upfront custom CSS editor. This is advanced functionality that deals with code, which we'll explore in a later tutorial in this course. [pic_right ]

Menu

You can create vertical, horizontal or hamburger menus with this element. Once added to a page, you can select a pre-existing menu or enter a name to create a new one. From there, you can type in names for your links. Once added, you can hover over each name and click the ellipses button to choose options for your link and add an URL. When you click on the element on the page, icons appear at the top with additional options.
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="490"] Need to create a hamburger menu? No problems with Upfront![/caption]
[/pic_right] [pic_left ]
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="490"] Place widgets anywhere you want on your site with the Widget element.[/caption]

Widget

With Upfront, you can place widgets anywhere on your page. Drop the element on the page, then click on the message Please select widget in settings to reveal buttons on top of the element. Click the gear icon, then select the widget you would like to include from the Upfront menu. Don't forget you can scroll down to see more widgets.
[/pic_left] [pic_right ]

YouTube

It's easy as easy as pie to add a YouTube video to your theme. Wait, scratch that. Adding a YouTube video is easier than making and slicing up a pie, even a ready-made pie. But I digress. Drag the YouTube element onto the page, enter the video's URL, then click Go. Clicking on the element reveals icons at the top with additional settings.
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="490"] All you need is a YouTube URL to add a video to your site – couldn't be easier![/caption]
[/pic_right] [pic_left ]
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="490"] Show off who like you with a Facebook Like box.[/caption]

Like Box

You can add a Facebook Like box to your site as easily as adding a YouTube video. Once you've dragged the element to your page, enter in your Facebook page's URL and click OK. Clicking on the element will also reveal buttons with more settings.
[/pic_left] [pic_right ]

Contact

I doubt adding a contact form to your site could be any easier than using this element. Drag it into place and your contact form is ready for action. Your admin account's email will be automagically added as the recipient address for your contact form, saving you from having to enter it yourself. The name, email and message fields will be displayed by default, and if you want to add or edit those fields you can click the element to reveal further options (buttons at the top of the element). Click the gear icon to pull up further settings.
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="490"] Add a simple contact form and then style it with custom CSS to look exactly how you want.[/caption]
[/pic_right] [pic_left ]
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="490"] The Code elements allows you to take advantage of Upfront's powerful custom CSS capabilities.[/caption]

Code

You can add your own HTML, CSS, or JavaScript code to your site with this element. After including it on the page, click on one of the options to Embed 3rd Party Code or Write Custom Code, then add in your code and away you go. We'll look at custom code in Upfront in-depth later in this course, but for now, just know that it's possible with this element.
[/pic_left] [pic_right ]

Tabs

The tabs element is a sleek way to add a lot of text into one area. When a user clicks on one of the tabs, new content will be displayed. Once you have added the element to the page, click on a tab, then double-click the content area to edit and replace the default dummy text. Clicking the other tab will reveal the dummy text for that tab, which you can edit by double-clicking that area.
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="490"] Create tabbed areas to help users focus on specific blocks of text.[/caption]
[/pic_right] You can also edit the tab names by double-clicking them. When you click on the element, buttons appear at the top so you can access additional options and add more tabs. [pic_left ]
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="490"] Short on space? The Accordion element can help you display more content.[/caption]

Accordion

The Accordion element is similar to tabs since they both display multiple pages of text in one area. Where the accordion element differs is that the headings are displayed vertically instead of horizontally. Clicking on a heading reveals the text, and clicking it again hides it. You can click a title to reveal sample text and double-click a title or text to edit them. Clicking the element also reveals icons you can click for more options including adding another section.
[/pic_left] [pic_right ]

Button

Adding a button to your site is as simple as dragging it onto the page. When you click on it, you will see buttons at the top to attach a link, adjust the padding and access more settings with the gear icon. You can keep the pre-styled button as-is or customize it by clicking the gear icon and adjusting the settings that appear in the Upfront sidebar.
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="490"] Add CTAs to your site and style them to suit you design.[/caption]
[/pic_right] [pic_left ]
[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="490"] Add a login form to any page on your site.[/caption]

Login

You can let users log into your site using a form, except with this element visitors will be able to view the form wherever you decide to place it on the page. No longer will you need to re-direct visitors to the default WordPress login page. Just drag the element from the menu to your page. That's it. If you want to customize it you can click on it to reveal buttons that lead to optional settings.
[/pic_left] [pic_right ]

Posts

With the posts element, you can add either a single post or a list of posts to wherever you want on the page. After dragging the element across, click one of the aforementioned options to display your post or list of posts.
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="490"] Display your blog posts and style how they look.[/caption]
[/pic_right]

Spacers and Arranging Content

If you haven't tried adding an element to the Upfront editor yet, try it out now. When you do, you may notice in some areas that a certain something is added to at least one side of the element. It almost looks like a blank space that takes up, well, space. Fittingly, these are called – wait for it – spacers. [pic_full_screen ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1364"] When you resize an element, a highlighted space will appear in the empty area beside it. We call these "spacers."[/caption] [/pic_full_screen] They help you add a bit of headroom for your elements and can help you achieve the ideal spacing, layout, and alignment you're trying to achieve. You can resize an element to add a spacer or hover over the area where two elements meet to reveal a + button that you can click to add a spacer. You can resize a spacer in the same way you would elements – by clicking and dragging the bars on either side until you achieve the size you want, then let go of your mouse click. Adding an element to the area where a spacer exists also resizes the spacer automatically.

Getting the Hang of Regions and Elements

We've covered a lot here but there's still a lot more you can do in Upfront to customize your site with regions and elements. But what we have explored in this tutorial should give you a jump start so you can start editing your site and watch it take shape. In this tutorial you learned how to:
  • Add and delete regions
  • Add different backgrounds including sliders, videos, images, and parallax
  • Start customizing elements
  • Arrange elements on the page
  • Use spacers to better arrange content and elements
In the next tutorial, you'll learn how to work with pages and posts in Upfront, as well as how to use Upfront's intuitive Responsive Mode to make adjustments to your site for multiple devices.

1133984.post_content:
As mentioned last lesson, the best way to cement new information is to put what you've learned to practice. So for this lesson's homework:
  1. Login to the Upfront site you created for the last lesson in this course and add a new region anywhere on the page.
  2. In the settings for the region, make the "Background Type" an Image, upload a new image, and then set the "Image Type" to parallax.
  3. Add a new YouTube element anywhere on your page and enter a YouTube URL for your video. Resize the element so it looks good!
  4. Add a new Contact element anywhere on your page and edit the basic settings so when a visitor enters their information is displayed over the field. Don't worry about editing presets for now as we'll explore how to use them later in this course.
  5. Resize the Contact element to create spacers to the left and right of it.
  6. Save your theme.

1133985.post_content:
In this second unit of the course, you learned how to:
  • Add and delete regions
  • Add different backgrounds including sliders, videos, images, and parallax
  • Start customizing elements
  • Arrange elements on the page
  • Use spacers to better arrange content and elements
Upfront great tool for building websites on the front-end because of its ease-of-use, but how have you found using Upfront? Have you played with adding different region types and elements? This discussion is your opportunity to ask any questions and chat with other students and course facilitators.

3.title: Assessment
3.description:
At the end of each unit, you are required to complete a multiple choice quiz based on the concepts you learned about in the tutorial and video. You need to achieve an 80% score in order to pass and move on to the next unit in the course.

If you find the quiz tough, it's because we've made it deliberately challenging – we want you to think about what you've learned (and really earn the certificate at the end of the course!). Each of the questions is based on what's been covered in the course material so if you've paid attention you should have no problems.

Good luck!

1133986.post_content:
Take your time, read through the questions and, if you need to, go back to the tutorial and video and review what you’ve learned before answering the quiz questions.

Good luck!

1133987.post_content:
Congratulations! You have successfully completed Working with Regions and Elements.

Now that you’ve learned how regions and elements work, we'll walk you through some more features of Upfront.

You can now proceed to the next unit, Pages, Posts and Responsive.

1.title: Unit Introduction
1.description:
Whether you want to add a detailed products and services page to your small business website or just need to publish up a quick blog post, Upfront lets you create posts and pages with ease from the front-end of your site.

No longer do you have to create pages in the backend of your site, not really knowing how it's going to look once published. With Upfront, you can create pages and posts and see how they will look on your site as you make edits. It really couldn't be any simpler!

Likewise, Upfront also provides a straightforward interface for responsive design so you can rearrange the content on your site so that it looks fantastic on any device.

In this tutorial, you’ll learn how to create and edit pages and posts, and how to use Upfront's simple responsive design interface.

Let's jump in!

2.title: Tasks

1133989.post_content:
Creating a New Post

To create a new post, click New Post in the sidebar. The Upfront post editor will load a blank post template, allowing you to type your blog post on the front-end (which is pretty cool!) and images and any other elements you want to your post. [pic_full_screen ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1364"] Write your posts on the front-end of your site and see your changes in real-time without having to click "preview."[/caption] [/pic_full_screen] You’ll notice the sidebar will change to display information you would normally see in the WordPress post editor, including the status of your post, its visibility, and publication date, as well as buttons to save draft and preview your post. There are further options for editing the post title and URL and meta description. If you click on the Cats / Tags tab, you’ll see more fields you can fill in for your post’s categories and tags. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] The Layout Template user interface in action.[/caption] [/pic_full] You’ll notice at the bottom of the sidebar, the Save button has been renamed Publish, so click this button when you’re ready for your post to go live. There are further options at the bottom of the sidebar for trashing your post – if you decide to delete it – undoing changes, and tweaking your post’s responsive design. When you’re done editing your post and you’ve saved your changed, click on the Upfront logo at the top of the sidebar to return to editing your homepage, or click Posts / Pages / Comments in the sidebar to edit another post or page. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="669"] When you click the Upfront logo, you’ll exit the editor so you can preview your homepage and site.[/caption] [/pic_full]

Creating a New Page

Creating a page is an almost identical experience to creating a new post, the only difference being that the Upfront post editor will load a blank page template instead. When you click New Page, the editor will load a blank page where you can add text, images and any other elements you want to create your page. Like creating new posts, the sidebar will display options for editing the page title and URL, post status, visibility, and publication date. [pic_full_screen ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1364"] Edit your page on the front-end of your site and see all your changes in real-time.[/caption] [/pic_full_screen]

Editing Existing Posts and Pages

To edit an existing post or page, click Posts / Pages in the Sidebar. Upfront will display a list of your posts ordered by date, as well as a list of your pages in another tab. When you hover over a post or page, you’ll be given options to Edit, View or Trash a post. If you select Edit, Upfront will load the post or page. If you choose View, Upfront will close the editor and display the post or page. If you choose Trash, Upfront will delete the post or page after an initial prompt. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Click Posts / Pages / Comments to edit, view or trash your existing posts, pages and comments.[/caption] [/pic_full]

Templates Vs No Template for Pages

When creating a new page in Upfront, you can choose to use a pre-built template. Each Upfront starter theme includes a bunch of pre-built templates, which you can customize to suit your design and layout. To use a template, click New Page and then under Page Settings go to Templates. In the drop-down box, choose the template you would like to use and click Apply. Your chosen template will load and you can go about customizing it how you like. While templates are available for pages, posts use the same design by default, which you can customize. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Choose a layout for your page, or even a layout templates for more specific customization.[/caption] [/pic_full] I’ll also quickly mention layout templates here, which allow you to create and reuse different page templates. Let’s say, for example, your client runs a business with offices in New York, Amsterdam, and Paris and wants a separate contact page for each office. With Upfront you could create a contact layout template with the layout, regions and elements exactly where and how you want them, and then apply that templates to each of the office pages, only having to update the addresses. No more having to create different pages from scratch or waste time repositioning elements. Upfront does all the heavy lifting for you. Using a layout template is similar to using a regular template. Click New Page and under Page Settings go to Templates. In the drop-down box, scroll to the bottom, choose a layout template and click Apply.￼

Making the Most of Data Elements

One of my favorite features when it comes to blogging with Upfront is that you can include both ordinary and data elements in posts and pages. What’s the difference between ordinary and data elements? Ordinary elements are things like images, text, contact forms, galleries, videos, sliders, and buttons. Data elements, on the other hand, contain dynamic data that comes from your site’s database, stuff like the title, date, categories, tags, author, featured images, and content of your posts. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Click and drag where you want to display data elements, such as author names, titles and categories.[/caption] [/pic_full] This means that with Upfront you can control, manipulate and position ordinary and data elements however you want. For example, say you want to display your featured images above the title of your posts. Easily done, just click and drag the element where you want. And if you want to show the publication date at the bottom of posts instead of the top, you can click and drag it, too.

Fine-Tuning Your Responsive Design

The Responsive Mode in Upfront aims to provide a seamless experience for editing how your site looks on different devices.

Before Editing in Responsive Mode…

Before you update the responsive layout for your site, it’s important to stop and think about how you want the site to look on different devices. Do you need all of the regions to display? What about your elements? Do you need all of those, too? Should the site look the same on both mobile and desktop? What about tablet devices? Do we need the video region to display on mobile phones? These are all important considerations because, more often than not, how a site displays on a desktop computer won’t naturally translate to the small screen of a mobile device. It makes sense to cut back on regions and elements you don’t need to ensure your site loads quickly on smaller devices.

Editing in Responsive Mode

To enter Responsive Mode, click the Responsive icon at the bottom of the sidebar. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Click the Responsive mode icon in the sidebar to edit how your site looks on different devices.[/caption] [/pic_full] There are three device types you can update your layout for: mobile (315px), tablet (570px), and default (1080px). Upfront will default to editing your site for desktop (default) devices. You can then switch to other devices by clicking the icons at the top of the page. A useful feature of Responsive Mode is the ability to show / hide elements for different devices. Say, for example, you want to only show your homepage slider to desktop users. Just go to the responsive design for the mobile version of your side and hover over the slider and an eye icon will appear. Click the icon and the slider will become invisible to mobile users who visit your site.
 
Don’t forget to check out how your site looks in responsive mode each time you make layout changes to your site so you can make further tweaks and ensure it always looks fantastic on different devices.

Using Pages, Posts and Responsive Mode

Now we’re getting somewhere! In the previous tutorials in this course, you learned how to make basic edits to your posts and page. Now we’re getting into the nitty gritty of editing full pages and posts and using Responsive Mode to check how they look on different devices. In this tutorial you learned how to:
  • Create a new post
  • Create a new page
  • Edit existing posts and pages
  • Use templates for pages
  • Use data elements
  • Edit your responsive design for different devices
I hope you enjoyed this tutorial and learned a thing or two about creating and editing pages and posts in Upfront, as well as fine-tuning the responsive design of your site. In the next tutorial, you’ll learn how to use presets to make designing layouts quicker and easier. See you next time!

1133991.post_content:
Let's cement what you have learned in this tutorial with some practical exercises!

This lesson's homework is to:

  1. Login to the Upfront site you created for this course and create a new post. Give it a new title and URL, add a few paragraphs of text and replace the feature image. Save your post.
  2. Create a new page and use the "Services Electrical Inner Page" template that comes packaged with the Fixer starter theme. Replace the page a title with your own title, replace the default page text with your own, and update the URL. Save your page.
  3. Open an existing page and trash it.
  4. Enter Responsive Mode and update the design for mobile devices. Make the text smaller for titles and hide any elements you don't want to display on smaller devices.
  5. Save your theme.

1133992.post_content:
In this third unit of the course, you learned how to:

  • Create a new post
  • Create a new page
  • Edit existing posts and pages
  • Use templates for pages
  • Use data elements
  • Edit your responsive design for different devices

How did you find the post and page creation experience? Have you updated your site's responsive design?

This discussion is your opportunity to ask any questions and chat with other students and course facilitators.

3.title: Assessment
3.description:
At the end of each unit, you are required to complete a multiple choice quiz based on the concepts you learned about in the tutorial and video. You need to achieve an 80% score in order to pass and move on to the next unit in the course.

If you find the quiz tough, it's because we've made it deliberately challenging – we want you to think about what you've learned (and really earn the certificate at the end of the course!). Each of the questions is based on what's been covered in the course material so if you've paid attention you should have no problems.

Good luck!

1133993.post_content:
Take your time, read through the questions and, if you need to, go back to the tutorial and video and review what you’ve learned before answering the quiz questions.

Good luck!

1133994.post_content:
Congratulations! You have successfully completed Pages, Posts and Responsive!

You're now ready to tackle some of Upfront's more powerful features.

You can now proceed to the next unit, Working with Pages and Custom CSS.

unit.post_title: Working with Presets and Custom CSS

1.title: Unit Introduction
1.description:
While Upfront provides a huge range of elements that look great on any site out-of-the-box, there will be times when you want to take your customizations a step further. That’s where presets and custom CSS come in.

Say, for example, you want all of the CTA buttons on your site to look exactly the same, right down to the typeface, colors, size and border style. Creating a preset allows you to capture all of this style information, which you can then apply to other CTAs uniformly without having to style each and every button.

Then there’s custom CSS and the ability to add your own code, which is undoubtedly one of Upfront’s most powerful features. You can edit CSS for everything across your site, including regions and elements.

In this tutorial, I’ll show you how to create and edit presets, and also walk you through some practical examples of how to use custom CSS to add some pizazz to your site.

Let’s dive in!

2.title: Tasks

1133996.post_content:
Working with Presets

In Upfront, presets provide a complete set of custom settings that you can create or edit for any element. But what does that mean exactly? The CTA example above painted a good picture, but let’s paint another one. Say you’re building a website for an electrician who would like to accept inquiries for quotes. The best way to do this is with a contact form, of course. However, this guy doesn’t want just one contact form, no, he wants multiple across his site. There’s a lot of potential for these forms to look messy, right? Not with presets! If you create one preset with the styling information for your first contact form – including the typeface, font sizes, colors, border styles and other appearance settings – it will save you having to create each contact form from scratch, ensuring all your contact forms across your site look identical.

Creating a New Preset Style

Here’s how you would go about setting up a contact form for the electrician with a preset style: 1. Drag and drop a Contact element onto your page 2. Click on the element once to bring up the Element Padding and Settings icons ￼[pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] When you click once on an element, icons for extra settings will appear at the top.[/caption] [/pic_full] 3. Click Settings and the sidebar will transform to display settings for the Contact element 4. Click Appearance. You’ll see that this element is using a default preset – all Upfront starter themes provide default presets for elements. For this example, though, we’re going to create a new preset. Click the drop-down box and in the empty text area give your new preset a name and click Add. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Name your new preset and click "Add."[/caption] [/pic_full] 5. This is where the fun begins! Now you can go ahead and style your contact form. Go through each of the options in the Static, Hover, and Focus tabs, update colors, typefaces, sizes, borders, animations, and other settings, and see your form transform as you make your changes. [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="254"] The styling options available for presets.[/caption] [/pic_full] 6. Click Save Element to save your changes.

Using a Preset Style

Now you can use the preset you just created for any form across your site. All you need to do is:
  1. Drag and drop a new Contact element onto another page on your site
  2. Click on the element once to bring up the Element Padding and Settings icons.
  3. Click Settings and in the sidebar click Appearance
  4. In the drop-down box, select the name of the preset you created and the style will be instantly applied to your contact form.
  5. Don’t forget to save your element.

Elements with Default Presets

All but four of Upfront’s 16 elements (Code, Maps, YouTube and Likebox) have default preset styles applied, which means you can choose from the default presets that come with the starter themes. This is handy if you want to emulate a particular style or edit an existing preset without having to start from scratch.

Working with Custom CSS

While presets in Upfront provide an easy way for you to save and re-use styles for forms, maps, sliders, menus and other elements across your site, custom CSS lets you add more advanced customizations to your site. And the best part about working with CSS in Upfront? When you update code, your changes are made in real-time so you can preview them as you go. Pretty neat, huh? In this tutorial, we’ll look at some practical examples of how to style elements with CSS, Global Theme CSS, how to apply it and also how to edit CSS for regions.

Styling Elements with CSS

Let’s start with a fairly straightforward example of styling an animated button with CSS.
  1. Drag-and-drop a new Button element onto your site, click the Settings gear icon. Create a new preset and give it a name.
  2. Style your button. I’m going to give my button a transparent background, set the typeface to Raleway, the weight/style Ultra Bold, set the text size to 20 and make it white, uncheck round borders, and set the border to 3px and make it green.
  3. Now click on the Hover tab and set the same appearance settings.
  4. Click Save Element. (already remember to save your progress!)
At this stage, we have a simple button that doesn't do anything on hover so let’s add some magic. Click the element, go into the settings and at the bottom of the sidebar click Edit Preset CSS. A CSS editor will appear at the bottom of the window. Paste the following text into the editor: [gist https://gist.github.com/jennimckinnon/d618cd84c95a439f41631c5d6ff222f9 /] Click Save in the CSS editor to save your CSS, and then hit Save Element in the sidebar. Your hover button should now have an animated effect. Pretty cool, right? [pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Now you see the background, now you don't! A very simple animation.[/caption] [/pic_full] It’s a pretty basic example of an animation you can achieve through customizing an element with CSS. Of course, you can do so much more! Let’s now have a look at styling global theme CSS.

Applying Site-Wide Global Theme CSS

Let’s try something a bit trickier – let’s style how underlines look beneath links. Inspired by this post at CSS-Tricks, I want to style my underlines so they feature a thin, black underline with space around the descenders, like so: ￼[pic_full ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="670"] Upfront really *is* cool.[/caption] [/pic_full]
  1. Drag and drop a Text element anywhere on your page (preferably somewhere with a white background) and enter the text "Upfront is really cool!"
  2. Highlight the text and create a new link and link "OK." I've linked my text to the Upfront theme page.
  3. Click on Theme Settings and then Global Theme CSS.
  4. Scroll down the CSS until you find /* links */. The code underneath this comment is for styling how links look in your theme. Replace it with the following CSS:
[gist https://gist.github.com/raewrites/276e9697f854388893b883ef3ff8f0c4 /] You'll also need to change the line height for your paragraph text to 1 so the underline sits nicely underneath the text. It's important to point out that this particular snippet won't look great on every site – it looks best on a white background – so feel free to experiment and see what looks good with your theme.

Styling Regions with Custom CSS

You can also apply custom CSS to individual regions. Why would you want to do that? Let's look at an example. Say you want to add a red border to a fullscreen region. You can achieve this by going to the settings for the region you want to edit and clicking Edit region CSS. ￼Add the following to the CSS editor: [gist https://gist.github.com/raewrites/6540bc2f196668443e5ecfdb171f36c5 /] Don't forget to hit Save. And here’s what it looks like: ￼[pic_full_screen ] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1364"] Adding a border to a region is simple with custom region CSS.[/caption] [/pic_full_screen] This is a simple CSS customization you might want to use for a one-pager site or even to emphasize a particular region on your site.

Working With Upfront Presets and Custom CSS

While presets allow you to quickly save and apply uniform styles across your site, it's custom CSS in Upfront that gives you the freedom to truly customize your website to look exactly how you want. In this tutorial you learned how to:
  • Create new preset styles
  • Edit custom CSS
  • Apply custom CSS to elements
  • Apply site-wide custom CSS
  • Apply custom CSS to a region
I hope you enjoyed this tutorial! I highly encourage you to experiment with custom CSS and presets in Upfront (don't forget, you can always undo your changes!). In the next tutorial, you’ll learn how to use the Upfront Builder to create beautiful themes of your own from scratch, without a starter theme.

1133999.post_content:
Let's apply what you learned in this tutorial to some practical exercises. For this lesson’s homework I want you to re-create each of the examples in the tutorial if you haven't done so already:
  1. Create a new preset style for a contact form,
  2. Style a button element,
  3. Style underlines for links using Global Theme CSS,
  4. Style a region with custom CSS to give it a red border, and
  5. Don't forget to save your theme when you're finished!
Note: The third task, styling underlines, is a bit tricky to implement so if it doesn't work for you and you don't feel comfortable playing with CSS code, just move on to the next task.

1133998.post_content:
This week's unit has focussed on how to create and work with presets and also make the most of one of Upfront's most powerful features, custom CSS and code. Specifically, you learned how to:
  • Create new preset styles
  • Edit custom CSS
  • Apply custom CSS to elements
  • Apply site-wide custom CSS
  • Apply custom CSS to a region
How did you go applying custom CSS to your site? Did you implement the examples? What other ideas do you have for presets and adding custom CSS to your website? This discussion is your opportunity to ask any questions and chat with other students and course facilitators.
